0.English Rule: A singular subject takes a singular verb
0.When to Use: When subject is singular (he, she, it, one person/thing)

1.English Rule: A plural subject takes a plural verb
1.When to Use: When subject is plural (they, we, multiple people/things)

2.When to Use: With he, she, it, or singular nouns

3.When to Use: With they, we, you, or plural nouns

4.English Rule: Add 's' or 'es' to verbs with he/she/it in present tense
4.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన కాలంలో he/she/it తో క్రియలకు 's' లేదా 'es' జోడించండి
4.When to Use: In present simple with third person singular

5.English Rule: Don't add 's/es' with I, you, we, they
5.Telugu Rule: I, you, we, they తో 's/es' జోడించవద్దు
5.When to Use: In present simple with all subjects except he/she/it

6.English Rule: Collective nouns can be singular or plural
6.Telugu Rule: సమూహ నామవాచకాలు ఏకవచనం లేదా బహువచనం కావచ్చు
6.When to Use: With words like team, family, group

7.English Rule: Everyone, somebody, nobody take singular verbs
7.Telugu Rule: Everyone, somebody, nobody ఏకవచన క్రియలను తీసుకుంటాయి

8.English Rule: Neither/either takes singular verb when alone
8.Telugu Rule: Neither/either ఒంటరిగా ఉన్నప్పుడు ఏకవచన క్రియను తీసుకుంటుంది
8.When to Use: When neither/either stands alone as subject

9.English Rule: Subjects joined by 'and' take plural verb
9.Telugu Rule: 'and' తో కలిపిన కర్తలు బహువచన క్రియను తీసుకుంటాయి
9.When to Use: When two or more subjects connected by 'and'

10.English Rule: With 'or/nor', verb agrees with nearest subject
10.Example: Neither he nor they are coming.

11.English Rule: There is + singular, There are + plural
11.Telugu Rule: There is + ఏకవచనం, There are + బహువచనం
11.Example: There is a book. There are books.

12.English Rule: Title of books/movies takes singular verb
12.When to Use: With titles, even if they look plural

14.English Rule: Each, every + singular noun takes singular verb
14.Telugu Rule: Each, every + ఏకవచన నామవాచకం ఏకవచన క్రియను తీసుకుంటుంది

15.When to Use: Before words starting with consonant sounds

16.When to Use: Before words starting with vowel sounds

17.English Rule: Use 'the' for specific things known to speaker and listener
17.Telugu Rule: మాట్లాడేవారికి మరియు వినేవారికి తెలిసిన నిర్దిష్ట విషయాల కోసం 'the' ఉపయోగించండి
17.When to Use: When both know what you're talking about
17.Example: The sun rises in the east.

18.English Rule: Use 'a/an' for non-specific things (one of many)
18.When to Use: When talking about any one thing, not specific

19.When to Use: With words like best, worst, tallest

23.When to Use: With United States, United Kingdom, etc.

24.English Rule: Don't use articles before meals in general

31.English Rule: Use 'the' when something is mentioned second time
31.Example: I saw a dog. The dog was brown.

32.English Rule: Don't use articles before proper nouns (names)

33.When to Use: When talking about a whole family

34.English Rule: Use 'the' with adjectives to make them plural nouns
34.When to Use: To refer to groups of people

35.English Rule: Use present simple for habits and routines
35.Telugu Rule: అలవాట్లు మరియు రోజువారీ పనుల కోసం వర్తమాన సాధారణ కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
35.Example: I wake up at 6 AM every day.

36.English Rule: Use present simple for universal truths
36.Telugu Rule: సార్వత్రిక సత్యాల కోసం వర్తమాన సాధారణ కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
36.Example: The sun rises in the east.

37.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన సాధారణం: కర్త + మొదటి రూపం క్రియ (I/you/we/they)

39.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన సాధారణ ప్రతికూలం: don't/doesn't + మొదటి రూపం

40.English Rule: Use present continuous for actions happening now
40.Telugu Rule: ఇప్పుడు జరుగుతున్న చర్యల కోసం వర్తమాన నిరంతర కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
40.When to Use: For actions in progress at speaking moment

42.English Rule: Use present continuous for future plans
42.Telugu Rule: భవిష్యత్తు ప్రణాళికల కోసం వర్తమాన నిరంతర కాలం ఉపయోగించండి

43.English Rule: Don't use continuous with stative verbs
43.When to Use: With know, love, hate, want, need, etc.

44.English Rule: Use present perfect for past actions with present result
44.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన ఫలితంతో గత చర్యల కోసం వర్తమాన పరిపూర్ణ కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
44.Example: I have finished my homework (now I'm free).

45.When to Use: For completed actions with present connection

46.English Rule: Use present perfect with just, already, yet
46.Telugu Rule: just, already, yet తో వర్తమాన పరిపూర్ణ కాలం ఉపయోగించండి

47.Telugu Rule: for/since తో వర్తమాన పరిపూర్ణ కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
47.When to Use: For actions from past continuing to present
47.Example: I have lived here for 5 years.

48.English Rule: Present perfect continuous: have/has been + V1+ing
48.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన పరిపూర్ణ నిరంతరం: have/has been + క్రియ+ing
48.When to Use: For ongoing actions from past to present
48.Example: I have been waiting for an hour.

49.English Rule: Use for + duration, since + starting point
49.When to Use: To show time period or starting point

50.English Rule: Use past simple for completed past actions
50.Telugu Rule: పూర్తయిన గత చర్యల కోసం గత సాధారణ కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
50.When to Use: For finished actions in the past

51.Telugu Rule: గత సాధారణం: కర్త + రెండవ రూపం (క్రమమైనది: క్రియ+ed)

52.English Rule: Use past simple with yesterday, ago, last
52.Telugu Rule: yesterday, ago, last తో గత సాధారణ కాలం ఉపయోగించండి

53.Telugu Rule: గత సాధారణ ప్రతికూలం: didn't + మొదటి రూపం

54.When to Use: For actions in progress at specific past time

55.English Rule: Use past continuous for interrupted actions
55.Telugu Rule: అంతరాయం కలిగిన చర్యల కోసం గత నిరంతర కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
55.When to Use: When one past action interrupts another
55.Example: I was sleeping when he called.

56.When to Use: For action completed before another past action
56.Example: I had finished before he arrived.

57.English Rule: Use past perfect to show which action happened first
57.Telugu Rule: ఏ చర్య ముందు జరిగిందో చూపించడానికి గత పరిపూర్ణ కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
57.When to Use: To show sequence of past events
57.Example: After I had eaten, I left.

58.English Rule: Past perfect continuous: had been + V1+ing
58.Telugu Rule: గత పరిపూర్ణ నిరంతరం: had been + క్రియ+ing
58.When to Use: For continuous action before past moment
58.Example: I had been working for 2 hours.

60.English Rule: Use shall with I/we for offers and suggestions
60.Telugu Rule: ప్రతిపాదనలు మరియు సూచనల కోసం I/we తో shall ఉపయోగించండి

61.English Rule: Future simple negative: will not/won't + V1
61.Telugu Rule: భవిష్యత్ సాధారణ ప్రతికూలం: will not/won't + మొదటి రూపం

62.When to Use: For actions in progress at future time
62.Example: I will be working at 5 PM tomorrow.

63.Telugu Rule: భవిష్యత్ పరిపూర్ణం: will have + మూడవ రూపం
63.When to Use: For actions completed before future time
63.Example: I will have finished by 6 PM.

64.English Rule: Future perfect continuous: will have been + V1+ing
64.Telugu Rule: భవిష్యత్ పరిపూర్ణ నిరంతరం: will have been + క్రియ+ing
64.When to Use: For continuous action until future time
64.Example: I will have been working for 10 hours.

65.English Rule: Use 'going to' for planned future actions
65.Telugu Rule: ప్రణాళికాబద్ధమైన భవిష్యత్ చర్యల కోసం 'going to' ఉపయోగించండి
65.When to Use: For intentions and plans already made
65.Example: I am going to visit him next week.

66.English Rule: Use 'going to' for predictions with evidence
66.Example: It's going to rain (dark clouds visible).

67.When to Use: For decisions made at moment of speaking

69.English Rule: Don't use 'will' after if, when, before, after, until
69.Telugu Rule: if, when, before, after, until తర్వాత 'will' ఉపయోగించవద్దు
69.Example: When he comes (not 'will come'), I will tell him.

70.English Rule: Use present simple for scheduled future events
70.Telugu Rule: షెడ్యూల్ చేసిన భవిష్యత్ ఈవెంట్స్ కోసం వర్తమాన సాధారణం ఉపయోగించండి

71.Example: When I was young, I would play cricket.

72.English Rule: Use 'used to' for past habits and states
72.Telugu Rule: గత అలవాట్లు మరియు స్థితుల కోసం 'used to' ఉపయోగించండి
72.Example: I used to smoke (but not now).

73.English Rule: Don't mix time references in one sentence
73.When to Use: Keep tense consistent unless showing time change

74.English Rule: In reported speech, present changes to past
74.Example: He said, 'I am busy' → He said he was busy.

75.English Rule: Subject pronouns: I, you, he, she, it, we, they
75.Telugu Rule: కర్త సర్వనామాలు: I, you, he, she, it, we, they
75.When to Use: As subject of sentence (who does action)

76.English Rule: Object pronouns: me, you, him, her, it, us, them
76.Telugu Rule: కర్మ సర్వనామాలు: me, you, him, her, it, us, them
76.When to Use: As object of verb or after preposition
76.Example: He loves her. Talk to me.

77.English Rule: Possessive adjectives: my, your, his, her, its, our, their
77.Telugu Rule: స్వత్వ విశేషణాలు: my, your, his, her, its, our, their

78.English Rule: Possessive pronouns: mine, yours, his, hers, ours, theirs
78.Telugu Rule: స్వత్వ సర్వనామాలు: mine, yours, his, hers, ours, theirs

81.English Rule: Reflexive pronouns: myself, yourself, himself, herself, ourselves
81.Telugu Rule: ప్రతిఫలన సర్వనామాలు: myself, yourself, himself, herself, ourselves
81.When to Use: When subject and object are same person

82.When to Use: When asking about people doing action

83.When to Use: When asking about people receiving action

85.English Rule: Use 'whose' to show possession in questions

87.English Rule: This/these for near, that/those for far

89.English Rule: Pronoun must agree with noun it replaces
89.Telugu Rule: సర్వనామం అది భర్తీ చేసే నామవాచకంతో సరిపోలాలి

90.English Rule: Use 'in' for months, years, seasons, centuries

92.Example: at 5 PM, at noon, at midnight

94.Example: at the bus stop, at home

95.Example: on the table, on the wall

96.Example: in the room, in the box

97.English Rule: Use 'to' for movement toward a place
97.Example: go to school, come to me

100.English Rule: Use 'with' to show accompaniment or tool
100.Example: with friends, write with a pen

101.English Rule: Use 'for' to show purpose or duration

102.English Rule: Use 'during' for specific period when something happens

104.When to Use: When there are three or more

106.Example: over the bridge, over my head

110.English Rule: Use 'since' for starting point of time

111.English Rule: Use 'until/till' for ending point of time

112.English Rule: Use 'about' for approximate topic or number

113.English Rule: Use 'of' to show belonging or material
113.Example: roof of the house, made of wood

115.When to Use: For what someone is able to do
115.Example: I can swim. It can rain.

116.English Rule: Use 'could' for past ability or polite request
116.Telugu Rule: గత సామర్థ్యం లేదా మర్యాదపూర్వక అభ్యర్థనకు 'could' ఉపయోగించండి
116.When to Use: For past ability or polite questions
116.Example: I could swim when I was young. Could you help?

117.Example: May I come in? It may rain.

119.English Rule: Use 'must' for strong obligation or certainty
119.Example: You must study. He must be tired.

121.English Rule: Use 'would' for polite requests or past habits
121.Telugu Rule: మర్యాదపూర్వక అభ్యర్థనలు లేదా గత అలవాట్లకు 'would' ఉపయోగించండి
121.When to Use: For politeness or repeated past actions
121.Example: Would you help? He would visit daily.

122.English Rule: Use 'ought to' for moral duty or advice
122.Telugu Rule: నైతిక కర్తవ్యం లేదా సలహా కోసం 'ought to' ఉపయోగించండి
122.When to Use: For what is right to do

123.English Rule: Modal + base form of verb (no 'to', no -s/-ing/-ed)
123.Example: can go (not 'can to go' or 'can goes')

124.When to Use: For what is not possible or allowed
124.Example: I can't swim. You cannot smoke here.

126.English Rule: Don't have to/need not for no necessity
126.Telugu Rule: అవసరం లేనప్పుడు don't have to/need not

127.English Rule: Have to/has to for external obligation

128.Example: Shall I help? Shall we dance?

130.English Rule: Would you like for polite offers
130.Telugu Rule: మర్యాదపూర్వక ప్రతిపాదనల కోసం would you like

131.English Rule: Could have/would have + V3 for past possibilities
131.Telugu Rule: గత అవకాశాల కోసం could have/would have + V3

132.English Rule: Must have + V3 for past certainty

133.English Rule: May/might have + V3 for past possibility

134.English Rule: Should have + V3 for past advice/regret
134.When to Use: For what was right to do but wasn't done

135.English Rule: Yes/No questions: Auxiliary + subject + main verb
135.Telugu Rule: అవును/కాదు ప్రశ్నలు: సహాయక క్రియ + కర్త + ప్రధాన క్రియ
135.Example: Are you ready? Do you like it?

136.When to Use: With action verbs in present tense
136.Example: Do you work? Does he study?

137.Example: Did you go? Did she call?

138.Telugu Rule: WH-ప్రశ్నలు: WH-పదం + సహాయక క్రియ + కర్త + క్రియ
138.When to Use: With what, when, where, why, how, who

139.When to Use: To ask about things or information

146.Example: How long have you lived here?

149.Telugu Rule: కర్త ప్రశ్నలు: WH-పదం + క్రియ (సహాయక క్రియ లేకుండా)

151.English Rule: Adverbs describe verbs, adjectives, other adverbs
151.Telugu Rule: క్రియా విశేషణాలు క్రియలు, విశేషణాలు, ఇతర క్రియా విశేషణాలను వర్ణిస్తాయి
151.When to Use: To describe actions or modify adjectives

152.Example: a beautiful big old round red Italian wooden dining table

154.English Rule: Add '-ly' to make adverbs from adjectives
154.Telugu Rule: విశేషణాల నుండి క్రియా విశేషణాలు చేయడానికి '-ly' జోడించండి

156.When to Use: Good with nouns, well with verbs

158.English Rule: Superlative: -est/most for comparing three or more
158.Telugu Rule: అత్యున్నత: మూడు లేదా అంతకంటే ఎక్కువ పోల్చడానికి -est/most

164.English Rule: Adverbs of frequency: always, usually, often, sometimes, rarely, never
164.Telugu Rule: ఫ్రీక్వెన్సీ క్రియా విశేషణాలు: always, usually, often, sometimes, rarely, never

165.English Rule: Place adverbs of frequency before main verb
165.Telugu Rule: ప్రధాన క్రియకు ముందు ఫ్రీక్వెన్సీ క్రియా విశేషణాలను ఉంచండి

166.English Rule: Place adverbs of frequency after 'be' verb
166.Telugu Rule: 'be' క్రియ తర్వాత ఫ్రీక్వెన్సీ క్రియా విశేషణాలను ఉంచండి

167.English Rule: Adverbs of manner usually go at end of sentence
167.Telugu Rule: విధాన క్రియా విశేషణాలు సాధారణంగా వాక్య చివర వెళ్తాయి

168.Telugu Rule: Very విశేషణాలు మరియు క్రియా విశేషణాలను తీవ్రతరం చేస్తుంది

170.English Rule: Zero conditional: If + present simple, present simple
170.Telugu Rule: శూన్య షరతు: If + వర్తమాన సాధారణం, వర్తమాన సాధారణం
170.Example: If you heat water, it boils.

171.English Rule: First conditional: If + present simple, will + V1
171.Telugu Rule: మొదటి షరతు: If + వర్తమాన సాధారణం, will + V1
171.Example: If it rains, I will stay home.

172.English Rule: Second conditional: If + past simple, would + V1
172.Telugu Rule: రెండవ షరతు: If + గత సాధారణం, would + V1
172.Example: If I had money, I would buy a car.

173.English Rule: Third conditional: If + past perfect, would have + V3
173.Telugu Rule: మూడవ షరతు: If + గత పరిపూర్ణం, would have + V3
173.Example: If I had studied, I would have passed.

174.Example: Unless you study, you will fail.

175.When to Use: If for maybe, when for sure
175.Example: If he comes vs When he comes

177.English Rule: Use 'were' (not 'was') in second conditional with I/he/she/it

178.When to Use: When condition and result are in different times
178.Example: If I had studied (past), I would be happy now (present).

179.English Rule: Use 'as long as' for condition with duration
179.Telugu Rule: వ్యవధితో షరతు కోసం 'as long as' ఉపయోగించండి
179.Example: You can stay as long as you want.

180.Example: You can go, provided you finish work.

181.Example: Take umbrella in case it rains.

182.When to Use: When something is likely to happen
182.Example: If I see him, I will tell him.

183.Example: If I were you, I would accept.

184.English Rule: Third conditional shows regret about past
184.Telugu Rule: మూడవ షరతు గతం గురించి పశ్చాత్తాపాన్ని చూపిస్తుంది
184.When to Use: For past situations that can't be changed
184.Example: If I had known, I would have helped.

185.English Rule: Passive voice: Object becomes subject + be + V3
185.Telugu Rule: కర్మ వాచకం: కర్మ కర్తగా మారుతుంది + be + V3
185.When to Use: When focus is on action or receiver
185.Example: The book was written by him.

186.English Rule: Use passive when doer is unknown
186.When to Use: When we don't know who did it

187.English Rule: Use passive when doer is unimportant
187.Telugu Rule: చేసేవారు ముఖ్యం కానప్పుడు కర్మ వాచకం ఉపయోగించండి
187.When to Use: When action matters more than doer

188.English Rule: Use 'by' to show the doer in passive

189.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన సాధారణ కర్మ వాచకం: am/is/are + V3

190.Telugu Rule: గత సాధారణ కర్మ వాచకం: was/were + V3

191.Telugu Rule: భవిష్యత్ కర్మ వాచకం: will be + V3

192.English Rule: Present perfect passive: has/have been + V3
192.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన పరిపూర్ణ కర్మ వాచకం: has/have been + V3

193.Telugu Rule: మోడల్ కర్మ వాచకం: modal + be + V3
193.Example: It can be done. It must be finished.

194.English Rule: Active voice is more direct and clear
194.Telugu Rule: కర్త వాచకం మరింత ప్రత్యక్షంగా మరియు స్పష్టంగా ఉంటుంది
194.When to Use: Prefer active unless specific reason for passive
194.Example: I wrote the letter (better than 'was written by me')

195.English Rule: In reported speech, present changes to past
195.Example: He said, 'I am busy' → He said he was busy

196.English Rule: Remove quotation marks in reported speech
196.When to Use: When converting direct to indirect speech
196.Example: She said, 'I'm happy' → She said she was happy

198.Example: She said, 'I like it' → She said she liked it

199.English Rule: Past simple changes to past perfect
199.Example: He said, 'I went' → He said he had gone

200.Example: She said, 'I will come' → She said she would come

201.Example: He said, 'I can help' → He said he could help

202.English Rule: Change time expressions: today → that day, tomorrow → next day
202.Telugu Rule: సమయ వ్యక్తీకరణలను మార్చండి: today → that day, tomorrow → next day
202.Example: She said, 'I'll come tomorrow' → She said she would come the next day

203.Example: He told me (not 'said me'). He said to me.

204.English Rule: Questions in reported speech: ask + if/whether or WH-word
204.Telugu Rule: పరోక్ష వాక్యంలో ప్రశ్నలు: ask + if/whether లేదా WH-పదం
204.Example: He asked, 'Are you ready?' → He asked if I was ready

205.When to Use: Avoid two negatives in same clause
205.Example: I don't have anything (not 'don't have nothing')

206.Example: I have some books. I don't have any books.

209.When to Use: few = not many (negative), a few = some (positive)
209.Example: few books (not many), a few books (some)

210.When to Use: little = not much, a little = some

211.English Rule: Both, either, neither - for two things
211.Example: Both books, either option, neither choice

212.When to Use: all = group, every = each one, each = individual
212.Example: all students, every student, each student

214.When to Use: see = general, look = direct attention, watch = movement
214.Example: see a bird, look at photo, watch TV

215.Example: I hear noise. I listen to music.

216.When to Use: say words, tell someone, speak language, talk to someone
216.Example: say hello, tell me, speak English, talk to him

217.Example: lay the book down, lie on bed

218.Example: borrow money from, lend money to

219.When to Use: its = belonging to it, it's = it is

220.When to Use: your = belonging to you, you're = you are

221.When to Use: their = possession, there = place, they're = they are
221.Example: their house, over there, they're coming

222.When to Use: to = direction, too = also/excessive, two = number
222.Example: go to school, too hot, two books

223.Example: It affects me. The effect is bad.

224.When to Use: accept = agree to take, except = not including

225.English Rule: Beside (next to) vs Besides (in addition to)
225.When to Use: beside = at the side of, besides = also

226.Telugu Rule: కొన్ని క్రియల తర్వాత క్రియార్థక నామం (-ing) ఉపయోగించండి
226.When to Use: After enjoy, finish, avoid, mind, etc.
226.Example: I enjoy reading. She finished working.

227.English Rule: Use infinitive (to + V1) after certain verbs
227.Telugu Rule: కొన్ని క్రియల తర్వాత అవ్యయం (to + V1) ఉపయోగించండి
227.When to Use: After want, decide, plan, hope, etc.
227.Example: I want to go. She decided to stay.

228.English Rule: Some verbs take both gerund and infinitive with same meaning
228.Telugu Rule: కొన్ని క్రియలు ఒకే అర్థంతో క్రియార్థక నామం మరియు అవ్యయం రెండింటినీ తీసుకుంటాయి
228.When to Use: With begin, start, continue, like, love, hate
228.Example: I like reading = I like to read

229.English Rule: Some verbs change meaning with gerund vs infinitive
229.Telugu Rule: కొన్ని క్రియలు క్రియార్థక నామం vs అవ్యయంతో అర్థం మారుతుంది
229.Example: stop smoking (quit) vs stop to smoke (pause to smoke)

233.Example: such a beautiful girl, such good food

234.English Rule: Countable nouns have singular and plural forms
234.Telugu Rule: లెక్కించదగిన నామవాచకాలకు ఏకవచనం మరియు బహువచన రూపాలు ఉంటాయి

235.English Rule: Uncountable nouns have no plural form

236.English Rule: Use capital letter for first word of sentence
236.Telugu Rule: వాక్య మొదటి పదానికి పెద్ద అక్షరం ఉపయోగించండి
236.Example: The sun rises in the east.

237.English Rule: Use capital letters for proper nouns

238.English Rule: Use capital 'I' for first person pronoun

241.English Rule: Use exclamation mark (!) for strong emotion

242.English Rule: Use comma to separate items in a list
242.Telugu Rule: జాబితాలోని అంశాలను వేరు చేయడానికి కామా ఉపయోగించండి
242.Example: I need bread, milk, and eggs.

243.When to Use: After words like however, therefore, etc.

245.When to Use: To show ownership by one person/thing

246.English Rule: Use s + apostrophe for plural possession
246.Telugu Rule: బహువచన స్వత్వం కోసం s + అపోస్ట్రఫీ ఉపయోగించండి
246.When to Use: When plural noun already ends in s

247.English Rule: Use quotation marks for direct speech

248.When to Use: To give more information about person
248.Example: The man who called you is here.

249.When to Use: To give more information about thing
249.Example: The book which I bought is good.

250.English Rule: Use 'where' for places in relative clauses
250.Example: The hotel where we stayed was nice.

251.English Rule: Use 'when' for time in relative clauses
251.Example: The day when I met her was special.

252.English Rule: Don't use comma before 'that' in defining clauses
252.Example: The book that I need is here.

253.English Rule: Use comma before 'which' in non-defining clauses
253.Example: My car, which is red, is fast.

254.Example: I was tired, so I slept.

255.Example: I slept because I was tired.

256.Example: Although it rained, we went out.

257.When to Use: To show opposite in same sentence
257.Example: I like tea but not coffee.

260.English Rule: Tag questions: positive statement + negative tag
260.Telugu Rule: ట్యాగ్ ప్రశ్నలు: సానుకూల ప్రకటన + ప్రతికూల ట్యాగ్

261.English Rule: Tag questions: negative statement + positive tag
261.Telugu Rule: ట్యాగ్ ప్రశ్నలు: ప్రతికూల ప్రకటన + సానుకూల ట్యాగ్
261.Example: You don't like it, do you?

262.When to Use: When two things happen at same time

263.English Rule: Use 'as soon as' for immediate sequence
263.Example: I'll call you as soon as I arrive.

264.Example: I had hardly arrived when it rained.

265.English Rule: Use 'no sooner...than' for immediate past sequence
265.When to Use: For one action immediately after another
265.Example: No sooner had I left than it rained.

266.Example: Either tea or coffee is fine.

267.Example: Neither tea nor coffee for me.

268.Example: He is not only smart but also kind.

269.Example: I don't know whether to go or stay.

270.When to Use: To explain why something is done
270.Example: I study so that I can pass.

271.Example: I came in order to help.

272.English Rule: Use 'in spite of/despite' + noun for contrast

273.Example: Even if it rains, I'll go.

274.English Rule: Use 'as' for simultaneous actions or comparison
274.When to Use: For things happening together or being similar
274.Example: As I walked, I thought. / He is as tall as me.

276.English Rule: Use 'as if/as though' for hypothetical comparison
276.Example: He acts as if he knows everything.

277.English Rule: Use 'wish' + past for present unreal situations
277.When to Use: For present wishes that aren't true
277.Example: I wish I were rich (but I'm not).

278.English Rule: Use 'wish' + past perfect for past regrets
278.Example: I wish I had studied (but I didn't).

279.English Rule: Use 'would rather' + base verb for preference

280.English Rule: Use 'had better' + base verb for strong advice
280.Telugu Rule: బలమైన సలహా కోసం 'had better' + మూల క్రియ ఉపయోగించండి

281.English Rule: Use 'used to' only for past (not present)
281.When to Use: For past habits or states no longer true
281.Example: I used to smoke (but not now).

282.English Rule: Use 'be used to' + gerund for familiarity
282.Telugu Rule: పరిచయానికి 'be used to' + క్రియార్థక నామం ఉపయోగించండి

283.English Rule: Use 'get used to' + gerund for becoming familiar
283.Telugu Rule: పరిచయం పొందడానికి 'get used to' + క్రియార్థక నామం ఉపయోగించండి
283.Example: I'm getting used to the weather.

285.When to Use: To cause someone to do something

286.When to Use: When you arrange for someone to do something

288.English Rule: Use 'the more...the more' for parallel increase
288.Example: The more you study, the more you learn.

289.English Rule: Use 'so do I/neither do I' for agreement
289.Telugu Rule: ఏకీభవించడానికి 'so do I/neither do I' ఉపయోగించండి
289.When to Use: To show you agree or have same situation
289.Example: I like it. - So do I. / I don't like it. - Neither do I.

290.Example: I do like it (really like it).

291.English Rule: Use double comparative: more and more/less and less
291.Telugu Rule: ద్వంద్వ తులనాత్మకం: more and more/less and less ఉపయోగించండి
291.Example: It's getting more and more difficult.

292.Example: to quickly run → to run quickly (better)

293.English Rule: End sentences with preposition in informal speech
293.Example: Who are you talking to? (informal, acceptable)

294.English Rule: Use inversion after negative adverbs at sentence start
294.Telugu Rule: వాక్య ప్రారంభంలో ప్రతికూల క్రియా విశేషణాల తర్వాత విలోమం ఉపయోగించండి
294.When to Use: After never, seldom, rarely, etc. at start
294.Example: Never have I seen such beauty.

295.English Rule: Use present tense in time clauses for future
295.Telugu Rule: భవిష్యత్తు కోసం సమయ వాక్యాలలో వర్తమాన కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
295.When to Use: After when, before, after, as soon as, etc.
295.Example: When I see him, I will tell him.

297.English Rule: Use 'may' for formal permission, 'can' for informal
297.When to Use: may for polite/formal, can for casual
297.Example: May I help you? (formal) / Can I help? (informal)

298.When to Use: -ing for causing feeling, -ed for experiencing feeling
298.Example: boring book (causes boredom), bored person (feels boredom)

299.English Rule: Maintain parallel structure in lists and comparisons
299.Telugu Rule: జాబితాలు మరియు పోలికలలో సమాంతర నిర్మాణాన్ని నిర్వహించండి
299.When to Use: Use same grammatical form for similar elements
299.Example: I like reading, writing, and speaking (all -ing forms)
